contextId.occurrenceNote: Someone who is arrogant speaks and acts as if he is better than other people. These two phrases have similar meanings and are used together to emphasize that Yahweh will punish them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: who is proud ... who is arrogant

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words mean basically the same thing and emphasize how quickly they will come. Alternate translation: "very quickly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: speedily and promptly

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "high" and "elevated" emphasize that the throne was very high and above everything around it. The height of the throne represents how great and powerful the Lord is. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: he was high and elevated

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "afraid" and "intimidated" mean the same thing and can be translated as one word. Alternate translation: "afraid" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: afraid or intimidated

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "briers" and "thorns" both refer to useless, thorny plants. It is not necessary to translate both words. Alternate translation: "thorn bushes" or "brier bushes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: briers and thorns

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "trap" and "snare" mean almost the same thing and emphasize that when Yahweh decides to punish the people of Jerusalem they will not be able to escape. Alternate translation: "he will trap the people of Jerusalem so they cannot escape him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: he will be a trap and a snare to the people of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize that they will be caught in the trap. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: ensnared and captured

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "briers" and "thorns" both refer to useless, thorny plants; they can be translated using one word. See how you translated these words in [Isaiah 7:23](../07/23.md). Alternate translation: "thorn bushes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: briers ... thorns

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "destroy" and "eliminate" mean basically the same thing. They are used for emphasis. Alternate translation: "He wants to completely destroy many nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: It is in his heart to destroy and eliminate many nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "briers" and "thorns" both refer to useless, thorny plants; they can be translated using one expression. See how you translated these words in [Isaiah 7:23](../07/23.md). Alternate translation: "thorn bushes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: thorns ... briers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two verbs mean basically the same thing. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "No one will live in it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: It will not be inhabited or lived in

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "laid waste" and "destroyed" mean the same thing and emphasize that the city was completely ruined. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Enemy armies will completely destroy Ar of Moab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Ar of Moab is laid waste and destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: As wandering birds, as a scattered nest

contextId.occurrenceNote: These mean the same thing. Alternate translation: "a beautiful crown" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: a beautiful crown and a diadem of beauty

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. This work is strange because God is using a foreign army to defeat the people of Jerusalem rather than helping the people of Jerusalem defeat their enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: his strange work ... his strange deed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "mourning" and "lamenting" mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of mourning. Alternate translation: "they will mourn deeply" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: mourning and lamenting

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "a vision of the night" is the same thing as "a dream." The two phrases emphasize that soon it will be like the invading army was never there. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: It will be like a dream, a vision of the night

contextId.occurrenceNote: These mean the same thing and emphasize how quickly the wall will fall. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: suddenly, in an instant

contextId.occurrenceNote: "a female lion or killer lion." This is a doublet with both phrase referring to a fierce lion. Alternate translation: "a lion" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: a lion, even a young lion

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize Yahweh's appearance. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: the glory of Yahweh, the splendor of our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "gladness" and "joy" mean basically the same thing, as do "sorrow" and "sighing." Together they emphasize the intensity of these emotions. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: gladness and joy ... sorrow and sighing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases "the greatness of his might" and "the strength of his power" form a doublet that emphasizes Yahweh's power. Alternate translation: "By his great might and powerful strength" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: By the greatness of his might and by the strength of his power

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases both refer to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "Why do you say, O people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: Why do you say, Jacob, and declare, Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh is the one who has done these things. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: performed and accomplished

contextId.occurrenceNote: This doublet means that the people gather together. Alternate translation: "they come together" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: they approach and come

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the greatness of their shame. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: ashamed and disgraced

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jacob" and "men of Israel" mean the same thing. Alternate translation: "you people of Israel who are like worms" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: Jacob you worm, and you men of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and indicate that Yahweh has kept himself from acting. Alternate translation: "I have kept myself from doing anything" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: I have been still and restrained myself

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize how badly the enemy had plundered them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: robbed and plundered

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "precious" and "special" mean basically the same thing and emphasize how much Yahweh values his people. Alternate translation: "Because you are very precious to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: Since you are precious and special in my sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these mean the same thing and emphasize that it is God who made the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: whom I have formed, yes, whom I have made

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "I" is repeated to emphasize the focus on Yahweh. Alternate translation: "I alone am Yahweh" or "I myself am Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: I, I am Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "I" is repeated for emphasis. Alternate translation: "I alone" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: I, yes, I

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses two similar expressions in order to strengthen his encouragement. Alternate translation: "Do not be afraid" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not fear or be afraid

contextId.occurrenceNote: These both refer to the descendants of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Jacob ... Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words "price" and "bribe" share similar meanings. Cyrus will not do these things for financial gain. Alternate translation: "he will not do these things for money" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: not for price nor bribe

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "ashamed" and "disgraced" mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of shame. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Their idols will leave them all completely ashamed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: They will all be ashamed and disgraced together

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words share similar meanings. They describe one who is beautiful and lives in luxury. Alternate translation: "very beautiful" or "very luxurious" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: dainty and delicate

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these refer to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Jacob, and Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "I" is repeated for emphasis. Alternate translation: "I myself" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: I, I

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two expressions in this context refer to destroying the people. Alternate translation: "destroyed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: cut off nor blotted out

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "a waste" and "desolate" mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the enemy has destroyed Zion and left it empty. Alternate translation: "Though you were completely desolate" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: Though you were a waste and desolate

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joy and gladness mean the same thing. Being found there represents being there. Alternate translation: "there will be joy and gladness in Zion again" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: joy and gladness will be found in her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "gladness" and "joy" mean basically the same thing, as do "sorrow" and "mourning." Together they emphasize the intensity of these emotions. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: gladness and joy ... sorrow and mourning

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words have similar meanings and emphasize the destruction of the land caused by the opposing army. Alternate translation: "your enemies have left your city empty and ruined" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: desolation and destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. Alternate translation: "inside the walls of my temple" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: in my house and within my walls

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that, although the people should have remembered Yahweh, they did not. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: so much that you would not remember me or think about me
